description:
Mollisia scopiformis is a species of fungus belonging to the genus Mollisia, which is a member of the family Mollisiaceae. It is a saprobic fungus, meaning it feeds on decaying organic matter in its environment.

Mollisia scopiformis is a small, cup-shaped fungus that typically grows on the decaying wood of deciduous trees, such as oak, beech, and maple. The fruiting bodies (apothecia) of the fungus are usually less than 1 cm in diameter and are initially curved or spoon-shaped, becoming more flattened as they mature.

The surface of the apothecia is smooth and grayish-brown to dark brown in color. The hymenium, which is the spore-bearing surface of the fungus, is pale grayish-brown to pinkish-gray.

Microscopically, Mollisia scopiformis is characterized by its asci (spore-bearing structures) that are cylindrical to clavate in shape and contain eight ascospores. The ascospores are ellipsoidal to fusiform in shape and are typically hyaline (colorless) or slightly pigmented.

Mollisia scopiformis is a common and widely distributed species, found in temperate regions across Europe and North America. It plays a role in the decomposition of woody plant material, contributing to the cycling of nutrients in forest ecosystems.
